courses.name: Biomedical Research at the Cutting Edge

cmCourseInfo.description: Explore the thought processes, logic, motivation, techniques, analysis and impact of recent high-profile publications to gain insight into the enterprise of science. Outstanding scientists present recent high-impact papers, and students will examine the research in depth, focusing on the underlying questions, experimental approach, results and significance. Restricted to first-year students. Not available for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Biomedical Research at the Cutting Edge
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SBI4U and SCH4U (Grade 12 University Preparation Biology and Chemistry); permission of Department

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course has restricted enrollment for newly admitted first-year science degree students with fewer than 4 credits.

Delivery Instructions

Course Delivery: Lectures will be delivered online synchronous and assessments will take place during the regularly scheduled class times. Classes are mandatory and will involve group work. Students will need access to Quercus and the ability to use collaboration software such as Bb collaborate, Teams or Zoom.

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey course covering all organ systems intended for students who are not proceeding further in Physiology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Basic Human Physiology
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Any 300-level PSL course taken previously or concurrently

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Term tests will be timed and will take place Tuesdays from 18:00 to 20:00 (Toronto time) on scheduled dates (TBA). Lectures 2h/week and optional help sessions 1h/week. Students will need access to the internet and Quercus and the ability to use collaboration software such Bb collaborate.

courses.name: Introduction to Physiologic Adaptations of Marine Mammals

cmCourseInfo.description: Systems approach to physiology of marine mammals in their aquatic environment. Highlights unique features of cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, urinary, and reproductive systems. Introduces relevant physiology, and makes comparisons to human condition and disease.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Physiologic Adaptations of Marine Mammals
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: (BIO120H1, BIO130H1), CHM136H1/CHM138H1/CHM151Y1 or permission of the course coordinator.

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Term tests will be timed and will take place Thursdays 12:00 to 14:00 (Toronto time) on scheduled dates (TBA). Active learning sessions (PRA) may be offered in the regularly scheduled practical times as student and TA safety allows and will also be recorded for remote learners. Students will need access to the internet and Quercus and the ability to use collaboration software such as Bb collaborate. If students cannot attend the in-person active learning for the entire term, please contact the Course Coordinator (c.wittnich@utoronto.ca) as soon as possible with the Subject line: “PSL280H Remote”.

cmCourseInfo.description: Credit course for supervised participation in faculty research project. Details at http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/course/rop. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

cmCourseInfo.description: Principles of neurophysiology, endocrinology and reproductive physiology for students enroled in Life Science programs.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Classes will be recorded and posted prior to scheduled classes. There will be online lecturer questions and answer periods on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays from 14:00 to 15:00 (EDT).

Delivery Instructions

Course Delivery: Lectures will be posted on online for viewing at any time. Term tests will take place during the regularly scheduled class times: Mondays, Wednesdays or Fridays 14:00-15:00 (Toronto - EST). Additional contact with students will be made through scheduled online tutorials or help sessions. Students will need access to Quercus and the ability to use collaboration software such as Bb collaborate, Teams or Zoom.

courses.name: Topics in Cellular, Molecular and Organismic Physiology I

cmCourseInfo.description: Control systems, feedback, networks, and both neonatal and adult cardiovascular and respiratory control are the topics examined in detail using homeostasis as a unifying theme. Tutorials involve computer simulations, case studies and/or experimental design. This course is designed for students in the Physiology Specialist and Biological Physics Specialist Programs, although permission is granted to students in other programs upon approval by the Department.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Cellular, Molecular and Organismic Physiology I

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

If you have been approved, a status of APP will appear; if you have been refused, a status of REF will appear. For additional information please contact Eva Eng at physiology.undergrad@utoronto.ca.

courses.name: Topics in Cellular, Molecular and Organismic Physiology II

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 19, 2020: delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: Molecular, cellular and organismic physiology of the central nervous system, gut, pancreas and glucose-sensing tissues; CNS diseases, obesity and diabetes are used as model systems. Tutorials involve computer simulations. This course is designed for students in the Physiology Specialist and Biological Physics Specialist Programs, although permission is granted to students in other programs upon approval by the Department.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Cellular, Molecular and Organismic Physiology II

cmCourseInfo.description: Improved clinical reasoning will reduce the current likelihood that most people will suffer at least one medical diagnostic error, errors that contribute to ~10% of patient deaths. Learn to apply strategies of critical thinking and principles of physiology to solve clinical cases. Shadow a healthcare professional. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Clinical Reasoning

Students will need to be able to access the internet and Quercus and to use collaboration software such as Bb collaborate, Teams or Zoom.

cmCourseInfo.description: Extend molecular biology concepts to current scientific literature in mammalian physiology. Apply these principles to disease and complex behaviours. Discuss bioethical issues raised by these techniques and their application. Benefit from three weeks in small group seminars lead by research professors focusing on current advances in mammalian molecular biology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mammalian Molecular Biology

cmCourseInfo.description: A problem-based laboratory course focused on the integration and control of organ systems to understand body functions. Enrollment in this course is restricted to students in the Physiology Specialist and Major Programs although permission is granted to students in other programs upon approval by the Department.

cmCourseInfo.description: Regenerative medicine promises to restore body function that has been lost due to disease, damage or age. Students will explore selected molecular, stem cell and tissue engineering developments to better understand how the body normally functions and how cells, tissues, and organs can be repaired or replaced.
cmCourseInfo.title: Regenerative Medicine

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides an in-depth review of the development and function of the male and female reproductive systems. Topics include sex determination and differentiation, steroidogenesis, gametogenesis, hormonal control of the reproductive axis, the female ovulatory cycle, fertilization and implantation, infertility and assisted reproduction approaches.
cmCourseInfo.title: Reproduction: Development and Function

courses.name: Pregnancy and Birth: From Implantation to Newborn Life

cmCourseInfo.description: General overview of the integrated physiological events associated with fetal development, pregnancy and birth. The approach emphasizes physiological processes using insights gained from studies of humans, animals, cells and genes. Where appropriate the clinical consequences of aberrant development are reviewed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Pregnancy and Birth: From Implantation to Newborn Life

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

courses.name: Cellular and Molecular Basis of Endocrine Disorders

cmCourseInfo.description: Explore how researchers uncover the molecular and cellular basis of endocrine disorders. Learn about experimental design, state-of-the-art research tools, and data interpretation. Topics include disorders in: hormone regulation, secretion and action; circadian rhythms; and sexual development and reproduction. Each week students engage in class discussion related to research seminars delivered by faculty.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cellular and Molecular Basis of Endocrine Disorders

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

courses.name: Integrative Metabolism and its Endocrine Regulation

cmCourseInfo.description: This course integrates the newest findings and experimental approaches from cellular and molecular biology into metabolic function at the tissue, organ and whole body level.
cmCourseInfo.title: Integrative Metabolism and its Endocrine Regulation

cmCourseInfo.description: Theoretical treatment of neurophysiology. Mathematical modeling and analysis of neurophysiological systems.
cmCourseInfo.title: Theoretical Physiology

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to systems neuroscience. A review of basic neuroanatomy and physiology followed by in-depth study of selected sensory and motor systems, with an emphasis on clinical applications in the second term. Students with an elementary neuroscience background progress to reading neuroscience literature on their own.
cmCourseInfo.title: Neuroscience: Systems and Behaviour

cmCourseInfo.description: Overview of the fundamentals of cellular and molecular aspects of brain function. Course material is updated yearly to reflect the rapid evolution of ideas in Neuroscience.
cmCourseInfo.title: Neuroscience: Cellular and Molecular
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSL300H1, PSL301H1, CJH332H1 or permission of instructor

cmCourseInfo.description: Explore topics in neurological disorders and treatments to reinforce and expand your knowledge of cellular and molecular neurophysiology. Course material is updated yearly to reflect the rapid evolution of ideas in this area.
cmCourseInfo.title: Neural Disorders
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: PSL300H1, PSL301H1, CJH332H1 or permission of instructor

courses.name: Mechanisms of Neural and Endocrinal Secretion

cmCourseInfo.description: Exocytosis and other aspects of secretion mainly in neurons and neuroendocrine cells, but also in pancreatic cells. Topics include synapse anatomy and physiology, synaptic plasma membrane and vesicle proteins, membrane fusion, genetic tools, endocrine secretion, plasticity in neurotransmitter release, diseases arising from secretion defects.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mechanisms of Neural and Endocrinal Secretion

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are live-streamed and recorded as per the meeting schedule (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance). Students will need access to Quercus and the ability to use collaboration software such as Bb collaborate, Teams or Zoom.

cmCourseInfo.description: Biophysics and molecular biology of ion channels. Topics include equivalent circuits for cells, molecular structure of voltage-gated channels, distribution of channels, relationship between single-channel and whole-cell recording, and regulation of channel function by voltage, phosphorylation, G-proteins and metabolites.
cmCourseInfo.title: Membrane Physiology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: Heart anatomy and development, ion channels and contractile proteins involved in cardiac and smooth muscle contraction are studied. Emphasis is on regulation of electrical and contractile function of kinases, metabolism, volume and ions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Molecular Aspects of Cardiovascular Function

cmCourseInfo.description: Development of the cardiovascular system from conception to adulthood with particular emphasis on maturational changes, age-related differences and developmental problems from cellular/molecular to whole organ/system.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cardiovascular Physiology

cmCourseInfo.description: This course covers the physiology underlying sleep and circadian rhythms, and their impact on important physiological processes and health. The integrative nature of the basic physiological processes is emphasized via discussions and clinical presentations. Overall, the aim is to present the full spectrum of integrative physiology from molecules and cells to understanding the sick patient.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sleep Physiology and Chronobiology

cmCourseInfo.description: This course compares and contrasts the physiological and anatomical adaptations exhibited by the different species of marine mammals in relationship to humans, with respect to diving.
cmCourseInfo.title: Diving Physiology of Marine Mammals

cmCourseInfo.description: Laboratory research project with reading assignments leading to a final report. By special arrangement with a Physiology staff member after admission to course. PSL498Y1 is recommended for students applying to the Physiology graduate program. Enrollment in this course is restricted to students in the Physiology Specialist and Major Programs, although permission is granted to students in other programs upon approval by the Department. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Project in Physiology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: (PSL304H1, PSL305H1)/PSL303Y1, PSL372H1, PSL374H1, permission of Department

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students must submit a completed PSL498Y1Y ballot by Friday, August 21, before being enrolled. Ballots are available on the course website: http://www.physiology.utoronto.ca/psl498y-project-physiology For more information please contact the undergraduate assistant at physiology.undergrad@utoronto.ca.

Delivery Instructions

An independent research project course with either fully remote or mainly in-person projects under faculty supervision. The location of the research depends on the supervisor and project chosen.
